message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest reactive arthritis, which is associated with HLA-B27 positive genotype. A hiking trip is not relevant to the symptoms. Positive anti-dsDNA antibodies suggest systemic lupus erythematosus, which is not likely in this case. Chondrocalcinosis is associated with calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease and is not relevant to this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest reactive arthritis, which is commonly associated with HLA-B27 positive genotype. A positive anti-dsDNA antibody suggests systemic lupus erythematosus, which does not match the patient's symptoms. There is no information to suggest a hiking trip or chondrocalcinosis of the left knee.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and family history, along with the presence of conjunctivitis, suggest a possible diagnosis of reactive arthritis (formerly called Reiter’s syndrome). HLA-B27 is commonly associated with reactive arthritis, making option (D) the most likely answer. Option (A) is not relevant to the patient’s presentation. Option (B) may indicate systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), but this diagnosis is less likely given the patient’s symptoms. Option (C) suggests calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease, which is not associated with reactive arthritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has frequent and painful urination, conjunctivitis, and a family history of autoimmune disease, which suggests a possible diagnosis of reactive arthritis. The additional symptoms of painful swelling of the knee and limited range of motion, along with the elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate and presence of WBCs in the urine, support this diagnosis. HLA-B27 positive genotype is commonly associated with reactive arthritis. The other options are not relevant to this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and history suggest a sexually transmitted infection, which can result in reactive arthritis and conjunctivitis. HLA-B27 is a genetic marker associated with reactive arthritis. The other options are not related to the patient’s symptoms or history.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest a possible sexually transmitted infection (STI) such as gonorrhea or chlamydia, which can lead to reactive arthritis. The presence of conjunctivitis supports the possibility of reactive arthritis. The patient’s mother’s autoimmune disease suggests a possible genetic predisposition. HLA-B27 is a genetic marker that is associated with an increased risk of developing reactive arthritis. Therefore, further evaluation is most likely to reveal a HLA-B27 positive genotype. The hiking trip two months ago and chondrocalcinosis are not relevant to the patient’s current symptoms. Positive anti-dsDNA antibodies are associated with lupus nephritis, but this is not suggested by the patient’s history and symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest an infection in his urinary tract and knee, indicating reactive arthritis. The presence of conjunctivitis and a family history of autoimmune disease further reinforce this possibility. HLA-B27 is commonly associated with reactive arthritis, while none of the other options are closely related.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest a sexually transmitted infection leading to reactive arthritis. The family history of autoimmune disease suggests a genetic predisposition, and HLA-B27 is associated with reactive arthritis. The other options are not relevant to this presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest reactive arthritis, which is associated with an HLA-B27 positive genotype. A history of a recent hiking trip or chondrocalcinosis would not be relevant to this diagnosis, and positive anti-dsDNA antibodies would suggest systemic lupus erythematosus rather than reactive arthritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and laboratory findings suggest a possible diagnosis of reactive arthritis, which is commonly associated with HLA-B27 positive genotype. The other options are not as relevant to the patient’s symptoms and laboratory findings.
